items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.

items.item_details:
Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the District until it has been approved by the Board of Trustees. Board Policy 6100 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval. All contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions exceeding the current bid limit of $86,000 shall have prior Board approval as a separate board item.
This consent item presents for Board approval: all purchase orders for this period, which includes purchase orders for administratively approved contracts exceeding $1,000, as well as additional contracts, although not executed by way of purchase order, are deemed appropriate to be added by the Purchasing Department.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts, purchase orders and contract revisions for the period of February 10, 2015 through March 9, 2015 as noted in the attached documents.
items.item_text: Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions
items.item_text_raw: 6. Ratification of Contracts, Purchase Orders and Contract Revisions

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease, requisition or purchase order ... [to] purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency is authorized by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
	 
Therefore, when considering the best interest for the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees award a piggybackable contract between the The Cooperative Purchasing Network (TCPN) and Office Depot without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. TCPN assist public agencies to reap the benefits of national leverage pricing, with no cost to the District, creating opportunity for greater efficiency and economy in the procurement of goods and services. 
	 
Attached are an affidavit of publication, award letters from TCPN to Office Depot for office/school supplies and contracts between TCPN and Office Depot for office/school supplies with a contract date effective 03/01/2015 to 02/28/2018, with an option to renew annually for an additional two years if agreed between TCPN and Office Depot.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to 'piggyback' on a contract with Office Depot.
items.item_text: Piggyback Office Depot Contract
items.item_text_raw: 7. Piggyback Office Depot Contract

items.item_details:
Per California Public Contract Code Section 20652, "the governing board of any community college district without advertising for bids, and when the board has determined it to be in the best interest of the district, may authorize by contract, lease requisition, or purchase order ... [to] purchase materials, supplies, equipment ... and other personal property for the district in the manner in which the public corporation or agency it authorizes by law to make the lease or purchase." The contract must be based on the same prices and upon the same terms and conditions of a negotiated contract between the supplier and another public corporation agency.
On March 9, 2010 (Board Item F-10), the Board of Trustees authorized the award of a contract without advertising for bids by determining that it was in the best interest of the District to 'piggyback' on the contract between the Western States Contracting Alliance (WSCA)/National Association of State Procurement Officials (NASPO) and Dell Marketing, LLP as the single source supplier of the District's technology equipment. This agreement enabled the District to obtain the highest value for every dollar spent on technology equipment through August 31, 2014.
	 
On August 26, 2014 (Board Item F-11), the Board of Trustees authorized the extension of the WSCA/NASPO Contract Administration approved Master Price Agreement B27160 Amendment Number 3, determining that it was in the best interest of the District to continue to 'piggyback' on the contract between WSCA/NASPO and Dell Marketing, LLP as the single source supplier of the District's technology equipment. This agreement enabled the District to obtain the highest value for every dollar spent on technology equipment through December 31, 2014.
	 
On January, 13, 2015 (Board Item F-13), the Board of Trustees authorized the extension of the WSCA/NASPO Contract Administration approved Master Price Agreement B27160 Amendment Number 4, determining that it was in the best interest of the District to continue to 'piggyback' on the contract between WSCA/NASPO and Dell Marketing, LLP as the single source supplier of the District's technology equipment. This agreement enabled the District to obtain the highest value for every dollar spent on technology equipment through March 31, 2015.
	 
On March 10, 2015, WSCA/NASPO Contract Administration approved Master Price Agreement B27160 Amendment Number 5, to extend the expiration date to September 30, 2015. Therefore, when considering the best interest of the District, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the extension of a piggybackable contract between WSCA/NASPO and Dell Marketing, LLP without the need to further advertise for bids on an already competitively bid contract. Attached are an affidavit of publication, an approval of award recommendation dated April 10, 2009 and the WSCA/NASPO Master Price Agreement B27160 Amendment Number 5.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize the District to extend a piggyback' on a contract with Dell Marketing, LLC.
items.item_text: Extension of Piggyback Dell Marketing, LLP Contract
items.item_text_raw: 8. Extension of Piggyback Dell Marketing, LLP Contract

items.item_details:
TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages) International Association Conference is being held in Toronto, Canada; March 25 - 28, 2015.  The Conference theme is: Crossing Borders, Building Bridges.  
As the largest organization focused exclusively on English language teaching for speakers of other languages, TESOL annually hosts more than 6,500 people from across the United States and around the world at its international convention. Educators at all levels attend to find a productive exchange of ideas and information and to feel the embrace of a dynamic professional community. 
	 
Margaret Muench, a full time ESL professor at San Jose City College, has been accepted to present at this conference on Thursday, March 26, 2015 along with Leslie Rice, also a full time SJCC ESL professor.  (Professor Rice's travel has already been approved by the Board.)  
	 
They will present: 
	 
Embedding Peer Tutors in ESL Classes â A Successful Bridge.
Making the transition to native-like academic writing is difficult for many English Language Learners.  Embedding a peer tutor within advanced writing classes can serve as their bridge to success. Tutor training methods and effective strategies for the use of tutors within the classroom is the focus of this practical presentation.
	 
Professor Muench will be paying for her own trip and will not require any District funds.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve out-of-country travel for Professor Margaret Muench at no cost to SJECCD.
items.item_text: Out of Country Travel - SJCC Faculty Member

items.item_details:
This agenda item is for the purchase, installation and configuration of 136 Wireless Access Points (WAPs) to replace 136 legacy WAPs at Evergreen Valley College by June 30, 2015. The purchase and installation services will cover the deployment of 111 indoor WAPs and 25 outdoor WAPs. This project will be funded with Instructional Block Grant funds and the total cost is not to exceed $200,000. 
	 
This is a starter wireless project to begin to address the wireless network needs at EVC. It is an initial phase of an entire network infrastructure modernization to include enterprise wireless, new network switches throughout the campus, fiber optics cabling (Measure G-2010 Bond Project 32702) and a new Main Distribution Facility (MDF) (Measure G-2010 Project 39310). The full effect (bandwidth) of these new WAPs will not be realized until the new network switches are installed in the respective buildings with the new wireless and connected to the core network in the new MDF. The new MDF is scheduled for completion in December 2015. The remainder of the network infrastructure modernization -- network switch upgrade, fiber optics cabling and remaining wireless upgrade -- is planned to begin summer 2015.
	 
This ICA and WAP purchase is based on RFP # G2010.0099 and pursuant to the Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies approved by the board on 8/26/14 (Measure G-2010 Bond Program).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of 136 Wireless Access Points (WAP) and the Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) for installation services per the attached Dasher Technologies ICA and Statement of Work and WAP quotation for a total cost not to exceed $200,000.
items.item_text: EVC Wireless Upgrade to Replace Legacy Wireless Access Points
items.item_text_raw: 14. EVC Wireless Upgrade to Replace Legacy Wireless Access Points

items.item_details:
AlfaTech, Consulting Engineers was awarded a Master Agreement by the Board of Trustees on May 25, 2012. 
	 
AlfaTech, Consulting Engineers was selected to provide professional services for lighting survey/recommendations, Schematic Design, Construction Documents and Construction Administration for the Site Lighting Project on the San Jose City College campus.  
	 
The purpose of this of the project is to bring the level of lighting on the main pedestrian pathways to the standards outlined by the Society of Illuminating Engineers.  AlfaTech, Consulting Engineers will provide professional services beginning with a survey of current conditions through construction documents and construction administration.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) SJCC-01 in the amount of $29,710.00 to AlfaTech, Consulting Engineers for the San Jose City College Site Lighting Project.
items.item_text: San Jose City College Campus Site Improvements Project #31116-04, Site Lighting– AlfaTech, Consulting Engineers, Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) SJCC-01
items.item_text_raw: 2. San Jose City College Campus Site Improvements Project #31116-04, Site Lighting– AlfaTech, Consulting Engineers, Project Assignment Amendment (PAA) SJCC-01

items.item_details:
This agenda item is for the purchase of 45 Wireless Access Points (WAPs) for San Jose City College along with installation and configuration services for 25 of the 45 WAPs this spring. The installation services will cover the deployment of 25 WAPs at high traffic indoor and outdoor areas at the Library and Learning Resource Center, Student Center and GE Buildings. The installation service includes knowledge transfer for training ITSS staff to configure the remaining WAPs per the new wireless network configuration provided existing network cabling is available. For the 20 remaining WAPs, 15 will be deployed in other areas that need replacement WAPs and 5 will replenish the District Office supply that was loaned for installation at the SJCC 100/200 building project last fall. The total cost is $56,910.49. 
	 
This is a starter wireless project to begin to address the high priority wireless needs at SJCC. It is an initial phase of an entire network infrastructure modernization project to include enterprise wireless and new network switches throughout the campus (Measure G-2010 Bond Project 31702). The full effect (bandwidth) of these new WAPs will not be realized until the new network switches are installed in the respective buildings with the new wireless and in the core network. The network switch upgrade and remaining wireless upgrade is planned to begin summer 2015.
	 
This ICA and WAP purchase is based on RFP # G2010.0099 and pursuant to the Master Agreement with Dasher Technologies approved by the board on 8/26/14 (Measure G-2010 Bond Program).
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the purchase of 45 Wireless Access Points (WAP) and the Independent Contractor Agreement (ICA) for network installation services of 25 WAPs per the attached Dasher Technologies ICA, Statement of Work and WAP quotations for a total cost of $56,910.49.
items.item_text: Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College Wireless Upgrade Starter for High Impact Areas
items.item_text_raw: 3. Measure G-2010 Bond Program: San Jose City College Wireless Upgrade Starter for High Impact Areas

items.item_details:
On August 26, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved an Agreement to Blach Construction Company in the amount of $41,639,729 to provide construction services for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions or District request design changes that require an adjustment to the contract scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 005 includes Work of: increasing storefront framing to match curtain wall, add conduits for data cabling between cable trays, revise security screens at Fitness Center windows, revise roof insulation materials, revise chemical waste piping material, and re-bidding of the low-voltage bid package previously redesigned for value engineering. The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.  
	 
Original Contract Amount                     $ 41,639,729.00
Previous Approved Changes                   ($343,156.86)
Change Order No. 005                               $726,529.90   
Total Contract and Changes                 $42,023,102.04
	 
The net change to Blach Construction Company’s contract as a result of all changes issued is $383,373.04, which equates to 0.92% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from the project contingency established in the project budget.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 005 in the amount of $726,529.90 to Blach Construction Company for the South Campus Development Project #32107 at Evergreen Valley College.
items.item_text: Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Change Order No. 005
items.item_text_raw: 4. Evergreen Valley College South Campus Development Project #32107 – Blach Construction Company Change Order No. 005

items.item_details: On October 14, 2014, the Board of Trustees awarded Cambridge West LLC in partnership with HMC Architects, with a contract to help the colleges update their educational and facilities master plans.  In November, 2014, Cambridge West Partnership teams lead a kick-off effort on the campuses of San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College.  The kick-off included interviews with faculty, staff, and students to get an understanding of where the colleges are and where we want to go as far as curricular offerings and facilities capacity.  Since then, the teams have completed internal and external environmental scans, surveys of faculty and students, analysis of classroom capacity and course productivity, and a series of walkabouts designed to capture the feel of the campuses from a facilities perspective.  This presentation will summarize the work done to date with preliminary observations from the work of the teams and suggestions for the future.
items.item_text: Update on Educational Master Plan and Facilities Master Plan
items.item_text_raw: 5. Update on Educational Master Plan and Facilities Master Plan

items.item_details:
The District intends to enter into a long term ground lease with a developer to develop the surplus 27.1 acres of land adjacent to the Evergreen Valley College campus.  
 
On January 27, 2015 the Board of Trustees approved Resolution No. 012715-1 informing the public of its intention to lease school property not needed for school classroom buildings and fixing the time and place at which bids to lease shall be considered.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees consider accepting or rejecting any bids received for the development of the Surplus 27.1 Acres located adjacent to the Evergreen Valley College campus pursuant to Resolution No. 012715-1.
items.item_text: 7:00 p.m. - Consideration of bids received for the Surplus 27.1 Acres and request for oral bids pursuant to Resolution No. 012715-1
items.item_text_raw: 4. 7:00 p.m. - Consideration of bids received for the Surplus 27.1 Acres and request for oral bids pursuant to Resolution No. 012715-1

items.item_details:
Pursuant to the CCCT Board Governing Policies, the election of members of the CCCT board of the League will take place between March 10 and April 25. This year there are seven (7) seats up for re-election on the board; one of those seven is a vacancy created by a board member that was not re-elected at the district level in November.
		 
Each member community college district board of the League shall have one vote for each of the seven seats on the CCCT board. Only one vote may be cast for any nominee or write-in candidate. The seven candidates who receive the most votes will serve a three-year term.
		 
The ten trustees who have been nominated for election to the board are listed on the attached document sheet in the Secretary of State's random drawing order of January 26, 2015. An official ballot for the election is also attached, which will record the seven candidates chosen by the Board of Trustees at the meeting.  The ballot will then be signed by the Board President and Board Secretary and mailed to the CCCT Elections Committee.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees choose seven of ten candidates nominated to serve on the California Community College Trustees Board.
items.item_text: CCCT Board Election 2015
items.item_text_raw: 5. CCCT Board Election 2015

items.item_details:
Proposition 39, which governs the District’s general obligation bonds, requires the establishment of a citizens’ oversight committee.  Following the passage of Measure G-2004 on November 2, 2004, the Board of Trustees took action on May 10, 2005 to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee. Measure G-2010 was passed by the voters on November 2, 2010, after which the Board of Trustees took action on December 14, 2010 to amend and restate the bylaws to allow for the existing committee to support both Measure G-2004 and Measure G-2010.
	 
The Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) is required by statute to meet at least annually to review the District’s Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 bond projects plan and to ensure that bond funds are being appropriately used as authorized by the voters.  There are no penalties defined in law for failure to convene a citizens’ oversight committee; however, the spirit of the law contemplates that districts will make every reasonable effort to ensure that the committee functions at least once each year to fulfill its statutory duties.  The current CBOC convenes quarterly for meetings.
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39, the Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee 
is required to have a minimum of seven (7) members comprised of one (1) student active in a community college support group, such as student government, two (2) Community-At-Large members, one (1) Senior Citizens’ Organization member, one (1) Business Community member, (1) Tax Payer’s Association member and one (1) Support Organization member. It is requested that the following applicant be appointed for a term to the Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee by the Board of Trustees. 
	 
New Member                            Representing                           Term
Zach Turminini                           Student                                        1
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees appoint the following Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee applicants to fill the current vacancy on the committee.
items.item_text: Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Bond Programs: Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Appointment
items.item_text_raw: 6. Measure G-2004/Measure G-2010 Bond Programs: Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Appointment

items.item_details:
On March 11, 2014, the Board of Trustees approved a contract to Kitchell CEM Inc. in the amount of $4,914,192.00 to provide construction services for the Career Technical Education Project, Buildings 100 and 200 at the San Jose City College. 
	 
Construction contracts commonly experience unforeseen conditions; District requested or design changes that require an adjustment to the contract, scope, price and/or duration in the form of a Change Order.  Change Order No. 008 is for changes necessary to ensure an ADA compliant path of travel between buildings 100 and 200.
	 
Kitchell CEM Inc. was issued DSA Construction Change Directive 002 to construct two ramps on the south side of the the 200 building. The cost to perform this additional work is (detailed in the attachment) which included the applicable increase in materials, equipment, labor, time extensions and overhead and profit.  The proposals have been reviewed to ensure the pricing reflects compliance with contract terms.
	 
Original Contract Amount                                             $4,914,192.00
Previous Approved Changes                                        $   526,840.00
Change Order No. 008                                                 $       7,819.00 
Total Contract and Changes                                        $ 5,448,851.00
	 
The net change to Kitchell CEM Inc. contract as a result of all changes issued is $534,659.00 which equates to 10.8% of the original contract.  This change will be funded from project contingency established in the project budget in expectation of this type of change.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Change Order No. 008 in the amount of $7,819.00 to Kitchell CEM Inc., for the Career Technical Education Project #31107-02, Buildings 100 and 200 at San Jose City College.
items.item_text: San Jose City College Career Technical Education Project #31107-02 – Buildings 100 and 200, Kitchell CEM Change Order No. 008
items.item_text_raw: 7. San Jose City College Career Technical Education Project #31107-02 – Buildings 100 and 200, Kitchell CEM Change Order No. 008

items.item_details:
Per its adopted governing principles, the Board of Trustees will evaluate its performance at the end of each meeting.
	 
The Board will consider two items in discussing its evaluation:
	 
1.To ascertain the effectiveness of the meeting in attaining the advancement of the Board's Global Ends Policy.
	 
2.To ascertain the degree to which Trustees adhered to the Board adopted Governance Principle: Trustees Code of Conduct.
